around.translation[0].definitions[0].def: surrounding or on all sides of something or someone
around.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The whole family was sitting around the dinner table.
The Romans built a defensive wall around the city.
She wore a beautiful silk shawl around her shoulders.
People crowded around to see what was happening.
We would hear the birds singing all around us.
around.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: A helicopter was circling around, looking for somewhere to land.
around.translation[0].definitions[2].def: in or to many places or parts of an area
around.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He wandered around the streets, looking in shop windows.
There are over 40 radio stations dotted around the country.
When I finished college, I travelled around for a while.
Since it’s your first day here, would you like me to show you around?
We started looking around for somewhere to live.
around.translation[0].definitions[3].def: in an area near a place or person
around.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Is there a bank around here?
When you’ve been around a person long enough, you start to know how they’ll react.
the new housing areas in and around Dublin
Catherine was the most beautiful girl for miles around.
around.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if someone or something is around, they are somewhere in the place where you are
around.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Why is there never a policeman around when you need one?
Jake went down to the bar, but there was no one around that he knew.
around.translation[0].definitions[5].def: on the other side of something, or to the other side of it without going through it or over it
around.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: If the gate’s locked, you’ll have to go around the side of the house.
There’s a door around the back.
She ran around the corner and straight into the arms of John Delaney.
around.translation[0].definitions[6].def: used to say that someone or something turns so that they face in the opposite direction
around.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: Rex spun around and kicked the gun from her hand.
Slowly he turned the boat around towards the open sea.
around.translation[0].definitions[7].def: used when guessing a number, amount, time etc, without being exact
around.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: There must have been around 40,000 people in the stadium.
The whole project will probably cost around $3 million.
Most guests started to make their way home around about ten o'clock.
around.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: That joke’s been around for years.
Manson has a reputation as one of the most stylish designers around.
around.translation[0].definitions[9].def: if something is organized around a particular person or thing, it is organized according to their needs, wishes, ideas etc
around.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: Why does everything have to be arranged around what Callum wants to do?
Their whole society was built around their religious beliefs.
around.translation[0].definitions[10].de: used to show that someone spends time in a place without doing anything useful
around.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: I’ve been waiting around all morning.
They could be seen hanging around street corners, watching the girls go by.
around.translation[0].definitions[11].de: a way around a difficult situation or problem is a way to solve it or avoid it
around.translation[0].definitions[11].ex: We must find a way around these difficulties.
The company is expected to get around this problem by borrowing from the banks.
around.translation[0].definitions[12].ex: Write your name on this list and pass it around.
Someone’s been moving the furniture around.
around.translation[0].definitions[13].de: used to show the length of a line surrounding something
around.translation[0].definitions[13].ex: Redwood trees can measure 30 or 40 feet around.
